newsitem.title: USA: Computer models disagree on freeze in U.S. Midwest.
newsitem.headline: Computer models disagree on freeze in U.S. Midwest.

text.p: Computer forecasting models were in disagreement on whether freezing temperatures would reach the U.S. Midwest early next week, meteorologists said.

"Next week we have a whole bunch of question marks," said Weather Services Corp's Joel Burgio. "If you believe the European model, there's a very strong cold air mass coming down" across the Midwest Tuesday and Wednesday.
The American model showed the cold air staying north.
Burgio said he compromised and forecast freezing temperatures for areas of Wisconsin, Minnesota and northern Iowa Tuesday morning.
"This particular forecaster is going with the American model," said Weather Express Chief Forecaster Fred Gesser.
Over the weekend, meteorologists agreed temperatures would turn colder Saturday morning with lows in the 30s degrees Farenheit to the northwest with 40s F elsewhere.
Gesser said scattered frost was possible in central Nebraska and northwest Iowa Saturday morning. Showers were expected to continue in Ohio Saturday.
Sunday should be warmer and mostly dry with a few scattered showers possible, they said.
Longer-range forecasts were inconsistent as the American and European models suggested different patterns. Gesser said the American model showed another wet pattern next weekend.
"The American model has the potential for wetness next weekend in the western corn belt," he said.
That could further delay harvest in Nebraska, he said.
